description.text:
The Bucketeer printer is intended to be a delta printer large enough to print a five gallon bucket. After scaling up the original delta's build area, I found it hard to stop it from wobbling and the MDF was not thick enough. I redesigned the parts to use the same 19-20mm aluminum beams, and they bolt in at the 60 degree angle. I have also included a drill guide to assist in drilling the holes. 
I have yet to test any of the parts, but they should be compatible with the original, with the exception of the end stop might miss the carriage. I will update as I make progress on this build.

My traceable shape things can be printed out very quickly with little plastic. I made these designs to be simple and intuitive so that anybody would be able to re-size them as needed.

Printer:

CraftBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

optimum

Infill:

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. As can be seen from the photo, an increased infill may be helpful as well.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For this project I started out with the geometric shape titled 'hexagonal prism' on TinkerCAD. I then adjusted the height to 2mm in order to get a strong but minimal thing. Next I adjusted it using Shift+click until the long side was approximately 120mm so that the thing would be large enough to use, as well as fit on a variety of printers including MakerBots. Next I used alt+click to make another hexagon. Then I re-sized it using shift+click to 110mm and moved it to the center of the original hexagon. Then, using the hide and group features, I had a final product.

Objective The purpose of this project is to help kids see and learn shapes by being hands-on. Using my tracers kids will be able to interact with shapes by being able to trace, cut, and color them. Audience The intended audience is kids 3+ with adult supervision, although these would be good for all ages to keep in there craft materials for when they need a perfect geometric shape. Preparation
  • Teachers wishing to modify the size of their own triangles will need to have access to a computer with internet access and be logged on to a free TinkerCAD account.
  • Tinkercad is easier to use with a mouse than with a tablet or trackpad, so computer mice are recommended.
  • No previous 3D design experience is required for the students, although familiarity with Tinkercad would be helpful.
  • Kids should have access to crayons/color pencils, safety scissors, and be supervised at all times.
    • Step 1: Adjust size Depending on your project and/or needs, you may need to adjust the size of the object. Simply download the thing from here and upload it to www.tinkercad.com. Next, press shift+click on one of the corners to adjust the size. Remember that you can adjust the snap in the bottom right corner which will allow you to be more or less accurate. Step 2: Print! Check out the beginning of this project for recommended settings. It would be good to let the kid(s) in on this process, but remember that there are lots of hot pieces on a 3D printer. Step 3: Trace Either have your kid(s) hold down the shapes and trace in or outside them, or alternatively tape the shapes down. Step 4: Cut Assist you kid(s) in cutting out the shapes. Using safety scissors is advised, and using non-straight scissors (like the ones that cut in wavy lines) could add more fun. Step 5: Color If you had the kid(s) trace inside of the thing, they could have just colored it all the way in already. Nonetheless, you can use this part of the project to also teach them about colors. Results The kids can use this to learn about shapes, colors, and scissor safety. This will give kids a good head start for their academic careers!

This is your companion for Magic the Gathering! 10/11/13 ADDED 1.1 LID AND BASE FILES for more authenticity with the grooves.
9/3/13 UPDATED THE LID FILE for a better and easier fit. The cube holds 2 Magic the Gathering decks with protective sleeves as well as two areas for dice or counters. The included card dividers also fit with ease. Best if printed with PLA. It will peal up at the corners if using ABS to print, so either use an ABS/Acetone slurry or other methods to hold it down.

Print with or without support depending on your printer and settings. I printed with support, 2 perimeters and .25 infill with a .35mm head.  
Use the BoxBase and BoxLid file since both together is too large in the DeckBox file.

description.text:
This is a basic right angle ruler design created by a grade 8 student. 
The ruler has small bumps at 5mm increments and is designed to help students and teachers in engineering and drawing lessons.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

uPrint SE Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2540
This was designed on Autodesk inventor using measurements and 2 simple extrusions and a pattern.

Objectives: To design and make a useful drawing tool for teachers and students
To make use of the school 3D printer
To focus on accuracy in making the tools Audience:
Students Grade 8+ in design classes
Teachers to potentially use the tools with other students Preparation:
Students to survey potential audience and find the most useful products to make, careful measurements must be taken to make sure their product is accurate. A sketch is drawn. Steps:
Create a basic L shape on CAD software using sketch and extrude.
extrude one 'bump' at the size at the inside corner of the part.
Use 3d pattern to copy the bump all the way down the length of the ruler
Use mirror at a 45 degree angle from the corner to copy the bumps to the other side of the ruler. Results: The tool printed in around 20 minutes and has been useful, embossed numbers would be a nice addition.

title: Beetle Bud Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
DIY Holder for iPhone ear buds that will look like a bug when completed.
Ear buds form the eyes, and the jack forms the mouth while also working to hold the cord bundle in place.
Place the ear buds in first and then wrap the cords around the bug as shown.  The way you roll it up doesn't really matter - there are a number of ways to do it on this thing... The volume control will naturally fit in the top of the insect, and the legs will also help hold the cords in place.
Best feature is that the cords don't become entangled during storage - and then just release the jack from the beetle's mouth and it will unwind like a spool of string!  The weight will make it unroll itself.
It is designed so that you can also use the main ear bud for a phone call (e.g. in the car)without having to remove it from the holder.  It looks like a funky beetle earring that will earn a few good curious stares from onlookers...  That way you can just roll it up when you are done.
The beetle's "horn" acts a guide for the wires.
Please post if you make one.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

Mojo

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

solid

Notes: The slots that hold for the ear buds in the correct orientation to look like a bug's eyes are intended to be a tighter fit - retaining the option to run a small round file through it if your resolution isn't the greatest on your machine and it needs more room (you can always take away material, but it is difficult to add it after the print!) As an option, you can epoxy Velcro to the feet so it can stick anywhere you put a Velcro pad (e.g. dashboard of your car). The "horn" is separate geometry and can be removed if it is not wanted. Print time is 4 hours. Volume of model material is 1.07 in3 and the support material is 0.6 in3.

description.text:
Objectives:
  • Make a visual and fun way to review the major battles of the Civil War
    • Audiences:

  • People who are learning about the United States Civil War

    • Steps! The idea for this project comes from my Social Studies class. While learning the battles of the Civil War, there wasn't a fun activity that taught us the material, so I set out to make one. Results: In the end, the students should have been able to correctly place each peg into the correct hole. Also, if the idea for this project intrigues them, it may get them involved in 3D Printing, thus introducing something new and exciting to the students.

description.text: This design uses small & powerful magnets (Buckyballs) that can be a gastrointestinal obstruction hazard. Print at your own risk. Something to keep the toy horses corralled in. Print, pop in 5mm Buckyballs, snap together to make a toy corral. (I used generic 5mm spherical magnets from aliexpress - they measured exactly 5mm in my digital calipers) I'm working on making this a customizable print, but haven't nailed down all of the parameters yet.

Printer:

Robo3D Kickstarter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20% 3D Hexagonal
Each piece takes 4 5mm magnets, use a pair of pliers to pop them into place. If the magnets do not require force to insert, try downscaling the object and printing again.

90% ScorchCAD (on my Android phone)
10% OpenSCAD on my desktop (fine tuning)

This is a simple paint pallet with space for primary and secondary colour mixtures.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

uPrint SE Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2540
This product was designed on Inventor using simple extrude and cut functions.

Objectives: To create a simple paint pallet product and 3d print
To learn simple skills in inventor to make the product in 3d Audience:
Art and design teachers and students who need more paint pallets but don't have the time to order them. Preparation:
First students need to decide the size of the pallet and how many colours they wish to include in their idea. Steps:
Draw a rectangle as a 2d sketch in inventor
Extrude it to 10mm thick
add a sketch to the top plane
draw circles in the arrangement you want
extrude/cut to remove material and create your pallet.
save as STL and print Results:
Our example was fairly small in size so I would be tempted to extend it and shell out the underneath to save material. Also colour labels would have been a nice addition.

author: pradlal

description.text:
The printed items make up a kit, to turn an empty 2 liter bottle into a horizontal terrarium.  This is to be made as a kit for teaching elementary school kids how plants grow, and how ecosystems can function as a self contained environment.  Includes a stabilizer to keep the bottle from rolling, a feeder/hopper to add soil down the length of the bottle, a custom cap that can be used to add water and seeds, an angle funnel to fit the bottle opening, and a seed cup to place seed.
Multiple bottles can be prepped with a single kit, just needing an additional stabilizer and cap printed.  The rest can be re-used.
Notes: The cap needs to be a flexible material, so the plug can fit. If this is not an option, the original bottle cap can be substituted

comments.text: If you have any issues with this, let me know directly.  The cap for this needs to be a flexible material, or the plug can't snap into place.

author: chev383

description.text: The Paladin from Rocket League. The tires are nothing to write home about but they'll get you by.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

I wasn't intending on doing a follow up piece to my previous sculpt, but got inspired by beardly goodness. Character sculpt at relatively low, medium and high and highest poly counts. File will need support material, but the top half of the model has been successfully printed on an UP printer, needing relatively low amount of supports. Should work great on a resin/SLA printer. Hoping to do a full test print soon, will see if a manually modelled support structure is needed for the hair. Was just too keen to make the file public and see what the community does with it. :) Edit: Confirmed printable on FDM! Thanks ichibey! Edit 2: Uploaded second option for all detail levels with a single shell, mostly to fix issues with the eyes. Thanks 3DWP! Zip file contains all detail levels. Sculpted in Zbrush, preview renders in Blender, final check and stl file saved from Netfabb. Approximate poly counts
Low = 137,000 tris
Med = 372,000 tris
High = 965,000 tris
Highest = 2,804,000 tris

comments.text: I have to make this.... looks like me when I walk in and a 40 hour print has failed at hour 39.  Crazy cool!
comments.author: Aggromemnon

comments.text: Indeed, quite the epic beard you have there sir! The two main tips for this print seem to be 1) If using Simplify3d, make sure to grab the  "Solid" version of the stl you want in the list as it will slice better. 2) Make sure there is enough support generated on the front tip of the beard, as there have been a few print fails for people.
comments.author: Aggromemnon

comments.text: Well...looks like I'm printing a bearded yell tonight :D.  I'm gonna split it down the middle (between the eyes) and print it in two pieces so I don't have to deal with supports.  I'll let you know how it turns out
comments.author: atooltoscream

comments.text: So, how'd it turn out?
comments.author: atooltoscream

comments.text: Not bad.  I used a dremel and friction welded the two halves together.  You can see the weld seam still and some places I goobered up, but it was nice not to have to pull supports off.

comments.author: 3DWP

comments.text: Hi, I have tried to print one but there are 4 solids.. The base, the head and 2 eyes. I Fixed the file by Boolean Union and making it solid. If you want I can provide a link so you update.. Some printers might print it but mine missed the eyes because they were too small as single artifacts.
comments.author: bendansie

comments.text: Hi, That hasn't been a problem for me in my experience with 3d printing services and FDM machines I've tried so I didn't worry about waiting for the often lengthy booleans to finish.
comments.author: 3DWP

comments.text: I used VisCAM software, a program for fixing STLs, it does a great job and took 3 seconds for the 372k version. I can send it to you if you want to check, all parts are one shell now and no problems in the mesh :-)
comments.author: bendansie

comments.text: Ah, I hadn't heard of or had access to VisCAM. Booleans in more art based programs can get a bit painful. I would like to have a look at the mesh thanks. Feel free to post it to me as a PM or upload as a remix. Whatever works for you.
comments.author: 3DWP

comments.text: You've got mail :-)

When I first got my Robo 3D R1+, one of the first things I printed out were the Riser feet designed by WheresWaldo (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868246) to help increase airflow and cooling of the Arduino components located at the bottom of the printer since this was recommended by many Robo 3d users. The Robo 3D came with 4 rubber L-shaped feet that slipped onto the bottom frame of the machine to prevent slipping. When I installed the risers, the rubber feet were useless. Unfortunately, my newly printed risers were flat and smooth on the bottom surface and did not provide traction or stability for the printer. As a quick solution, I used a few small squares of rubber shelf liners for grip. I thought it was a waste to not utilize those L-shaped rubber feet, so I redesigned the Robo Riser and added some channels on the bottom for the rubber feet to pressure fit into. Now, the Robo 3D has it's risers for improved air flow and also better table traction!

description.text: This is a cooling fan mount for the MakerGear Mosaic printer. The printer comes with two fans: a small one for cooling the extruder and a large one for cooling parts being printed. The Mosaic instructions explain how to mount the extruder fan, but no provision is provided for mounting the cooling fan.

I was able to use extra hardware that MakerGear supplier with the printer for mounting the cooling fan. The extruder wire harness includes extra connectors for expansion. I used one pair to power the cooling fan. I wired the cooling fan to D9 on the RAMPS board. This allows your skeiner to turn the fan on and off. See http://reprap.org/wiki/File:Arduinomega1-4connectors.png. D9 is located in the upper left.

author: orthoid

description.text: Koch variant

Wanted to have my spools on bearings but also like the MM3's OE spool holder. This is a very V1 attempt at a spool holder that works like a tire balancer. Two cones hold the spool allowing for a slight variance in the ID and the width of the spool. I measured the few different spools I had on hand to get the parameters, can't remember what they were now. Filaments.ca and MTW spools fit like a dream. One could mod the cone shape easily to tailor it to their spools.
One cone is on a threaded shank, the other on matched threaded nut. Two 608 bearings keep the shank aligned to the M8 bolt that comes with the MM3. It's currently sized to work with the two jam-nuts that come with the MM3 kit, but it could be a bit cleaner with some small spacers that only contact the inside race of the bearings.
The knob on the nut is a bit massive, but it feels great to turn and gives you a nice bit of torque to mash the threads tight. Makes loosening easy too. (and it looks neat-o.)
NOTE: I'm not a great modeler. The meshes are clean, but a bit janky for sure. Prints fine for me with S3D.

Printer:

MTW - mendelMax3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15 - 35% fast hex

Notes: -White filaments.ca PETG - because PETG is the best at everything -4 solid layers top and bottom -1 or 2 shells depending on your preff -supports are necessary for the well in the nut but not for the shank. S3D supports are da'bomb -at 35% infill they're much more heavy duty than they need to be. I'll probably remake these at 20%

Clean up IDs Hobby knife, touch of beveling if needed. I did a touch to seat the bearings easier, will design that in for V2. same goes for thread interface. Had to nip a mil or so back on the nut side to get that smooth action. Snap those bearings in son I bought 100x 608 bearings off ebay.ca for like 28 bucks CDN. 608 bearings are better known as standard skateboard wheel bearings. Super common, super cheap, super handy, get some.

Tire / Prop balancer Same basic principle as a tire balancer or prop balancer. Works super well in PETG, haven't tried it in anything else. Primary reason for making this was to keep the ridged spools form hitting the M5's that mount the spool holder plate to the 2020 extrusion at the back. and I wanted constant tension on the filament with the bearings. Cinema 4D is better than your other favorite modeling suite.

title: Aurora A3 MK8 Extruder Strain Relief

description.text:
This Should Work...
I'm still testing it, but it appears to take a lot of the bending/strain off the motor wires.
You'll need three mini zip ties to mount it. The constant back-and-forth of the print head, bending the extruder motor plug wires ever so slightly finally took their toll. All four wire started to fail and the extruder motor started skipping. rendering prints a disastrous failure. After painstakingly re-soldering all four wires to their micro-sized clips for the motor plug, I decided I didn't ever want to do that again! I designed this Strain Relief bracket to fit the very tight spaces between the extruder motor and its mount on the Aurora a3 Prusa I3 printer. I may work for other printers with the MK8 extruders - I don't know for sure.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

JG Aurora A3 Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: This Thingi is only 1mm thick in most places, so printing at 100% Infill doesn't increase the time much, and you'll want that extra strength.
It does need supports (touching buildplate only).

Zip Ties Required You'll need to fit the top-part in first and then flex the bottom slightly around the base of the motor and then it will snap into place. You could take off the extruder from the mounting plate, but that's a pain. There are 3 places for zip ties to mount it to the extruder motor.
One is at the bottom to hold it together.
The other two are at the top to ties the two sides together with all those wires wrapped inside. You'll find guides built-in to this thingi to help put the zip ties in the right places - See photo of MK8 on printer.

This is a display stand and some basic screw heads to complete lillykill's NN-14 blaster. To get the blaster for this stand go here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1227111 The screw heads are a rough Torx format just to kind of match the single image I could find of the actual prop. You can use real screws of course but you have a 3D printer, why not just print them? They just super glue on and come in three sizes. The Large are for the grip screws, the medium for most of the other screws and the small for the couple of small heads per side. From what I can find the actual gun is the NN-14 manufactured by LPA, not the NN-44 based on fan sites. I couldn't find what LPA stands for but in all honesty I didn't look that hard. Note that this display stand is modeled for a 110% scale of lillykill's model. If you print the NN-14 at 100% you will need to scale this down. If you printed the blaster larger than 110% then you'll need to scale this up appropriately. I would offer that lillykill's model be scaled even bigger than 110%. At 110% the trigger guard is on the small side for an adult finger and the hand grip doesn't fit the average hand. 115% or 120% may be the better option and if I re-print it I'll print the handle and trigger piece at 120% to check for size. You'll need a printer with a print space at least 110mm x 210mm and a height of around 75mm. I modeled the display stand with some random height surface blocks just for some visual interest to the stand.

Printer:

MendelMax 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

10%

Notes: I printed it in PETG at 240C extruder, 75mm/s, 60C bed covered in 3DEeez but whatever settings are good for you.
You could paint the letters in a contrasting color but that's about it.
Imported lillykill's model into Studio Max then just used some basic shapes to create the stand around it.

comments.text: Thanks for modeling the screw heads! I'll totally use them on my model.

This was a remixed of a keg model I found on the internet. Very honestly I must say I'm not able to give proper credit because I found the model somewhere, downloaded and simplify the mesh till it was good to print. Then I added the tag on the top of the keg and merge it into a single stl object. I wrote a post on a blog I started to publish pictures of my prints and potential tips. It can be found here: https://converdbmakes.wordpress.com/

This thing is a remix of "Victorian Hurricane Lamp" by loubie.
The following changes were made: Was planned electrification with appropriate through-hole.
The frieze on CasteMiddle has been deleted because it is too breakable.
The connection between Base and SwirlingBase has been made with 5 mm holes/dowels.
The connection between SwirlingBase and CastlelMiddle has been made with round threaded pin.
The LightHolder has been melted with the CastelMiddle.
Depth has been created to house the lamp holder (interlocking rubber band).
The lampShade was little modified to contain properly the bulb. 2_SwirlingBaseReduced is a version reduced to 150.000 triangles for a more easily download. In the picture 4 there is a slightly different model

Taulman Nylons are amazingly strong but are very hygroscopic.  When printing large objects that take more than a day to print, the filament can absorb enough moisture from the air (despite copious amounts of desiccant inside a nearly airtight enclosure) to significantly degrade and weaken your print due to the moisture being driven off at the extruder nozzle.  If you can hear very light snapping / popping noises at the extruder nozzle while extruding there is too much moisture in the filament...even fresh filament from Taulman, despite being vacuum packed with desiccant often has too much moisture in it to print cleanly.    To solve this problem I created a heated enclosure to keep the filament dry.  I also added a pointer to the spindle to give a visual indication that the filament is feeding into the printer.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I used ABS for the box bottom and top and Taulman 910 for the spindle and heat shield (ABS distorts from the heat)

Things you will need First clean and trim any supports from the parts. 1) Find, buy or salvage a light socket and cord from a lamp or light fixture. 2) Dimmer or rheostat of some kind or proper wattage light bulb to attain and maintain about 140 degrees Fahrenheit (Roughly 25 watts) 3) You will also need a roll of 2" or wider aluminum foil tape. 4) Black semi gloss spray paint 5) Thermometer Light socket salvaged from bathroom vanity fixture and 60 watt incandescent bulb

Assembly instructions First thing to do is to test fit the light socket and drill or cut a hole in the bottom half of the enclosure where you want the cord to exit. Then line the entire inside of the lower portion of the box with aluminum foil tape
(THIS IS IMPORTANT!!!)
as it will prevent the ABS from distorting or melting from the light bulb which just rests on the bottom of the box. Install the light socket and light bulb then route the cord through the hole you made...I added foil tape around the hole to hold the cord in place and to block off excessive amount of air from coming in through the gap. Now for the heat shield. Apply aluminum foil tape to the bottom of the curved portion of the heat shield and then spray paint it with semi gloss black paint. This will help dissipate the heat from the light bulb evenly to the upper half of the enclosure. Place the heat shield into the lower half of the enclosure and snap it into place. Install a spool of nylon by inserting the spindle into the spool (this should be a snug fit) if it is too loose the spindle will not rotate with the spool. You can add a little blue painters tape to it if needed. Set the spool and spindle in the lower half of the enclosure and then thread the filament out through the slot in the top half and finally position the top half onto the lower half of the enclosure. If you have a Makerbot you can hang the box on the back of the printer or just set it on the bench surface. All that is left to do is to adjust the temperature by selecting the proper size bulb 20 to 30 watts or use a larger bulb 60 to 100 watt and a rheostat or light dimmer. Use a thermometer or infrared temp sensor to monitor temperature until you get a stable 140 degrees Fahrenheit. Completed set up Heat Shield Taulman 910 covered with Foil tape and painted semi gloss black Spool and spindle set into lower half of enclosure Adjusting rheostat to achieve 140 degrees Fahrenheit

double delta robot with software for arduino This is a simpeler version of my triple delta robot (see https://youtu.be/bnRF_SKKLgc )
It is possible to add more layers to this design. You can make it a triple, tetra, penta, or hex delta robot.

additional parts needed. part list
  • 3 digital servos (Dynamixel AX-12A) with connectors
  • analog servo (micro servo ES-07)
  • Arduino Uno board
  • 30 ball joint sets (www.famotec.de KG-20 item nr 10013)
  • 1400 mm of straight iron wire (diam approx 1.2mm)
  • 30 cotton swabs made from 73 mm tubes
  • 14 M2 bolts of various lengths
  • 6 M2 nuts
  • 12V 1A power supply
  • 3 diodes (ie 1n4002)
  • resistor 10K
  • schottky diode (ie BAT41)
  • 7805 voltage regulator
  • 100uF/16V capacitor
  • 2 100nf capacitors
  • 400mm of nylon fishing wire (diam 0.3 mm)
  • epoxy glue ,ca glue and hotmelt glue
  • some wires and connector stuff
    • Dynamixel servos must be set to 19230 baud (103 in register 4). The addresses must be set to 2,3 and 4

title: Landing gear bracket for Multiplex FunCub

description.text:
Initial text:
This is a replacement for the genuine landing gear bracket of the famous Multiplex FunCub. It is deivided into a few individual pieces to save support material. Just glue them together after printing. Update 2016/07/03:
The first prototype was a close copy of the genuine part, but it turned out, that at least my printed part was not rigid enough. Two of the lugs holding the landing gear wire broke after the third not-so-soft landing.
So I made a reinforced version with longer lugs of increased cross section. I also added two holes on each side that can be used to add additional strenght by wrapping zip ties around the side lugs after the wire is installed.

description.text:

Fixings are 4x 8mm M3 or M4 screws and nuts.
2 minutes to design in Tinkercad so easy to change for different sized slot tables or clamps. is public so just search for

Print this page

Fan hole is 50mm or 2"  
Cut out the slots

title: Platonic Polyhedra 1: Dodecahedron & Parts Thereof
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
"It is related to Hippasus that he was a Pythagorean, and that, owing to his being the first to publish and describe the sphere from the twelve pentagons, he perished at sea for his impiety, but he received credit for the discovery, though really it all belonged to HIM ( for in this way they refer to Pythagoras, and they do not call him by his name)." Let's hope I don't get drowned for showing you how to construct a dodecahedron! Yes, Greeks used to care about maths so much that they killed people for publicly disclosing the existence of a dodecahedron. Thank goodness Intellectual Property has moved along since then and we have patents, copyright, and creative commons. You'd never hear of someone dying for disclosing the existence of a new iPhone (sorry, I shouldn't joke about Foxcon employees being bullied to death). This is my standard CAD System test drive. I first studied the geometry of the dodecahedron when Uwe Meffert asked me to write a solution to his Skewb Ultimate. Uwe Meffert is the owner of Meffett's puzzles in Hong Kong, he invented the Pyraminx about two or three years before Ernõ Rubik invented the Büvös Kocka (which became known as "The Rubik Cube" after patent difficulties). Meffert asked me to write a solution for the Junior Pyraminx with David Singmaster after reading an academic paper I coauthored about the Masterball with David Joyner, group theory expert at USNA. I agreed to write the "Junior Pyraminx" solution, met with Zingmaster, but asked Meffert to rename the JPM to "Pyramorphix". He accepted. Even today, Uwe Meffert's site still has the solution to the Pyramorphix on a page called "jpmsol.HTML" http://www.mefferts.com/puzzles/jpmsol.html The artwork I did for the JPM was incorrectly copied for the Japanese solution leaflet, so before I agreed to do the Skewb Ultimate for Uwe, I first sought approval for my artwork to be used. Hence I worked out how to draw a dodecahedron from basics, and how to draw one by subtracting from a Cube. Results are still available today, though I do really want to rework the end images. They look a bit 90's! http://www.mefferts.com/puzzles/solution-skewbultimate1.html
I see how easy it is to create a Dodecahedron to learn about the systems handling of planes, reflection, rotation, and other basic operations. Just so happens Dear Daughter needs a 12 sided dice.

description.header: I just hope she's not starting to play Dungeons & Dragons(!).
description.text:
Basic files included showing how I make this. From a Circle, 1 line and an angle for the second line, the rest of it is good old fashioned Descriptive Geometry as taught at Imperial College, London, in 1995. Once you form the Pentagon from basic principles, rotate it greater than the angle required around two edges. This then has 1 intersect point at the common corner not on the orginial face plane. Form two new planes from the axis of rotation and this intersect point. Draw a LARGE circle on those planes and cut outwards to remove all excess material. You have arrived at the "first three faces" - model one above. Next form a mirror plane from the original sketches and the top, centre intersect point. Mirror the solid. Repeat to form all five L2 Pentagons. Merge solid. This is the "First Half" (6 faces formed) - the next part model I've uploaded. Mirror or rotate into position to form the 2nd 6 sides, then merge - voila - you've got the finished Dodecahedron. The sort of thing we should teach more often in Universities these days. This has no numbers on it, so you can write your own. NEW: 10-sided added, and rounded and squished. also blank. Simply pull the faces 1 & 12 until they are points (alternatively extrude those faces larger and then cut back from them to form the new faces). Define the points you've made as two point of an axis, define that as "Z-direction" and scale x as 1, y as 1, and z as 0.707 NEW: Octahedron, constructed in ProE.
Parts thereof to show the way for maths and CAD jockeys.
Start with a Square, draw four equilateral triangles, revolve them to form new volumes. Form planes from intersection points and the axis of rotation. Cut away from those planes. Voilà. Octahedron.

description.text:
This model was created for the MakerEd Challenge.
With this kit, students and teachers can assemble several different molecules pair to help learning in the classroom. Furthermore, it is also possible to explain the molecular geometry, showing the angles between the bonds.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

These objects are very simple, I used Tinkercad to create them with a few geometric shapes and some intersections. Ball with an intersection I did some balls and multiple cylinders positioned them in the right position with the exact angle using the rotation tool. In the spheres in the inspector I I configured as 'Color' and the cylinders I I configured as 'Hole' after group these components I have intersections. ball with three intersections Bond with two intersections

Objectives The objective of this kit is to help students and teachers in the classroom, showing some molecules physically and how the links in addition to the students to learn the amount of necessary connections and the angle between them. Audiences high school;
chemical classes;
entrance exam preparation courses;
home schooled students; Preparation Students should know a little chemistry, molecules, chemical composition and molecular geometry. Step 1: Research about molecular geometry I studied molecular geometry in high school, but I had to give a revised to remember all connections, their names and angles. Step 2: Create the model In Tinkercad I created models using geometric shapes and their intersections.
The challenge here is to position the links at the correct angle.
  • The way 'linar' is the simplest, it 180 ° between its links.
  • The way 'trigonal planar' is 120 ° between its links.
  • The way 'tethahedral' has 109.5 ° between all its connections.
  • The form "trigonal bipyramidal 'has three connections 120 ° in the middle and 180 ° between the two other connections.
  • The way 'octahedral' has 90 ° of all your calls.
    • Results After printing the students should be able to mount several different molecules and understand how the molecular geometry.

You may need to compensate for how your printer works. I've shrunk my files when printing with -0.3 mm but has polished and fine-tuned to get the perfect fit.

description.text:
This is a 160mm wide ball robot prototype, wich uses two modified servos as motors, an arduino and a bluetooth module for control and a entirely 3d printed frame. I will complete the full instructions soon.
If you want a smaller robot, check my version 2 here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1458520 More projects here: https://juanggengineering.blogspot.ca

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

60% or above for ther ball and 20-30% for the rest.

Notes: I printed it with pla, but abs should work well. If printing with abs, be carefull with wrapping or the two sides of the ball wont fit properly.

1) 3d printed parts: -Print all of them, except the magnet support where you have to choose between the simple one, or the V2, wich includes a servo.
-Allso you can print the central part of the sphere in two halves or all together.
-I printed all the parts (except the head) at 0.3 mm layer height, but 0,2 works well.
-Please use high infill for the ball, specially side 1 and side 2 (60-80%) 2) Non 3d printed parts used: -Two modified Futaba S3003 servos, or any standard servo modified for continuous rotation.
-One 9 gr micro servo
-Some magnets (I took one from a hard disk and the others from a magnet game, but use whatever magnets you want)
-2x10 mm wood screws for the internals
-3x15 mm wood screws for the ball
-some zip ties
-Plastic glue (I used super glue)
-Some 6 mm plastic bbs
-Control Board:
·Arduino Nano
·L293D motor diver
·Hc-06 Bluetooth module
·MPU 60-50 (I havent tried it yet)
·Usb conector
·5 volt battery (any external phone battery will work) 3) The assembly -Sphere The two halves of the central sphere (If you have printed it in one time obiously skip this step) Glue them together. Put some wheight on it. Screw the two sides to the central part. Sand it until its smooth. Note where does each side go and in what position. -The internals Parts needed. Place the two modified servos on its place. Screw them in place. Attach the flywheel. Parts needed. Fix the magnet to the servo with zip ties. Screw the micro servo to the support. Add another zip tie. Fix it to the internal frame. Screw it to this side. -The head support: Parts needed. Place four bb´s on their holes. Push them down until it goes through its hole. With that result. Place the bb´s again and cover it with that piece. Put your magnets there. Glue it to that. Add a cable to secure that cover or simply glue it. Remember to put the smooth side facing down.

description.text: As a photographer I have lots of electronic devices that take all kinds (and numbers) of batteries. Yeah there are loads of AA and AAA battery boxes out there, and sure you can stick paper in them to indicate whether they are charged or not, but when you buy CR2's or CR2430's then boxes are thinner on the ground so you leave them in the packaging, then use one, then the one remaining bumbles around your bag, short circuits and/or leaks. Pah, not any more.

There are 3 varieties, round for 3 or 4 batteries (very inefficient), linear and offset for 2, 3 or 4 cells. If you think you might want a 6, let me know and I'll knock one out. All with slots so you can add your "I'm charged" indicator. As well as a lid, these also need a bolt printing out as well.
Designed for a single cell, CR2 and CR123 cells are not rechargeable, but the 18650 is. Don't forget a lid as well.
Urgh, coin batteries. As well as a lid, this pot also has an insert (print 2 of the inners) to separate the batteries. Yep, 3... I had 3. Sorry.

Sorry about the order the files appear to be in, there doesn't appear a way to sort alphabetically other than drag things around. If you have a preference for a single box, your best bet is probably to download the whole lot (bandwidth permitting) and then let your operating system order them.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Pretty much anything goes. All the pots are designed to use the Ultimakers "Print one-at-a-time" setting as well, so you can load the print plate and not worry about the drag edges.

I started with the CR2 pots that I needed quite urgently, then moved to the 2430's and the insert. Then I realised the 18650's would be good for transport as well, CR123's are no different. I then got clever with the same style for the AAA range... fail (in my opinion). So I designed the linear and offset pots for them.

title: TAZ 5 strengthened Extruder Body with filament tube holder

description.text:
This is a remix from wantmys2000 strengthened extruder body. I added a filament tube holder and straightened the "flap" above the extruder stepper. The top screw hole area is redesigned so the part can be mounted with a M3x50 screw istead of a M3x60 which is sometimes hard to get.This modification shouldn't affect stiffness.
The spacer isn't modified, I only attached it to have all neccesary parts in one place.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

as thick as you want to go

Infill:

I used hexagon infill @ 25%

Notes: Use ABS or PETG (as I did). PLA will not survive the heat from the stepper.

comments.text: Just to clarify, this will fit the juniper extruder mount and x carriage only.  It will not fit the olive extruder mount and x carriage
comments.author: discojon

comments.text: True. For people that don't have the project names in mind (like me): Like the orginal by wantmys2000, this fits to the original, stock TAZ 5 extruder mount.

description.text:
This game board prevents your cat from eating all her treats at once. Put the food in the middle of the board, it's a fun challange for most cats to get them out. This one is quite big to make it a little more challenging for our cats, so it's splitted into 4 parts to keep the print time of each part low. This way it should also be possible to print it on small printers.
If you are not sure if your cat likes it, print only one part first and try it!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

as thick as you want to go

Notes: Be sure your esteps / flow rate is tuned quite well or the parts wont fit! They should fit with a little bit of force so no glue is necessary.

comments.text:
I only made one quarter and my cat loves it. But I saved a lot of time and filament by cutting off the bottom by ~15mm in slic3r. Then I glued it to a piece of MDF wood.
BTW: it's pretty difficult to clean all the cat's drool off ;)

Thing that Connects Cubotic-Cubes fast and easily Actually I test different variants. Both variants I uploaded here have advantages and disadvantages. Which is the best for you depends on material, printer, objectives. Easy to print in PLA (0.4 layer-width), is the One-Part version. And it pressures the Cubes really tight. (this would be my advice for the beginning). The Clipping-Assembly version should be printed in ABS (better for clip-lifetime). (in general this variant is more offen reusable but all in all not so easy to make (and offers actually not so much pressure). Cubes can be donwloaded there:

title: Cherry 3D Printer X_-_Carriage NEMA16/NEMA17 Motor Adapter

description.text:
Little adaptation to install Nema16/Nema17 motor in X_-Carriage using the same screws from X-_Carriage to fix the 28byj-48 Stepped motor and the 624 Bearings. The holes to screw from Nema16 and Nema17 are the same spacing. If your motor shaft is more longer than 20mm, perhaps you will need to add thickness between the motor and the support. I added a new piece to add thignes between Motor and Adapter if you motor shaft is to long.
It's a plate 2mm thick. You can scale in the Z axis to add or remove thick. You will need change the screws from you motor by other longer to go through you motor and this piece. To mount:
Put four M3 hex Nuts in this piece.
Screw this piece to X_-_Carriage with the same screws and the bearings. I added some washers to adjust the bearings position.
Screw your motor to this piece with you new long screws, from the back of the motor.

Printer:

Cherry 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

comments.text: My motors don't have mounting holes that go all the way through the body, so if I install the adapter on the X carriage, there's no way to mount the motor to the adapter! And if I mount the motor the adapter first instead, then there's no way to install the adapter to the X carriage...

author: stalkerface

description.text:
Hello there, i'm new in 3D printing and i think that you still have the same problems like me, which forces you to abort the print. One of these problems is the movement of the filament. Sometimes it works really well. But always when i leave the room some diabolic thing happens to the filament. Mostly the spool tangles up and the print is ruined. I mentioned that the way of the filament from the spool to the PTFE tube doesn't guide very well. So the guide needs help from anothe guide. Great, isnt't it? Since that adaptation I've got no more problems with tangle of the spool. You only need two things: Bearing: 1x 608 ZZ (8x22x7 mm), also knowen from skateboard wheels
Screw: 1x M3x55 mm Use the position of the screw that holds the layer, which is the visible bottom of your printer. Also showen in the picture. That's it!

Printer:

CTC Creator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

60-75%

C-3PO, sometimes spelled See-Threepio and often referred to as Threepio, was a 3PO unit protocol droid designed to interact with organics, programmed primarily for etiquette and protocol. He was fluent in over seven million forms of communication, and developed a fussy and worry-prone personality throughout his many decades of operation. Along with his counterpart, the astromech droid R2-D2, C-3PO constantly found himself directly involved in pivotal moments of galactic history, and aided in saving the galaxy on many occasions. C-3PO was built from spare parts by Anakin Skywalker, a human slave who lived in Mos Espa, a city on the Outer Rim world of Tatooine. C-3PO's memory was erased, though R2-D2's memory was not. C-3PO and R2-D2 were assigned to the Alderaan cruiser Tantive IV, where they served senator Bail Organa for nineteen years. At some point during this time, 3PO's right leg was fitted with a mismatched droid plating.[14] I print this model from white ABS . I also sanded it and painted with humbrol model paint.
You can download R2D2 in this same scale from my account !
More figures soon !

title: V6 hot end  c clamp mod to hold 12mm proxy sensor

description.text:
As i bought a full steel X carriage the china type.
it has multi ways to setup your extruder.
what i did was go bowden style with a Mk8 cheap extruder kit ( the yellow one)
bought a cheap vulcano ( also china knock off )
and a long heat break 1.75.
I then screwed the heatbreak in the tapped 6mm hole leaving the hotend hole open.
put a lock on under neath and a hot end body on the top to secure it even futer.
this also allowed me to get the bowden tube in place
Gaining about 1 inch in Z travel.
and !!!
redesigned the V6 clamp to hold the proxy sensor for auto bed leveling.

author: joe3504

description.text:
The atom is the smallest particle capable of identifying a chemical element and participate in a chemical reaction.
The study of the atom began in ancient Greece with the philosopher Leucippus and his disciple Democritus: for them, the atom was the smallest component of all existing matter. Since then impossible to divide it into smaller parts.
The course of history, many scientists and scholars have attempted to define the atom as its form, giving rise to various theories about its physical constitution. There arose the atomic models.
These models are very easy to do, the only challenge is to position the components of each model in the correct position to represent the characteristics of each model.

Objectives Help teachers in the classroom showing students the evolution of atomic models with a physical model is easier for students to identify the differences in each of them. Audiences high school;
chemical classes;
entrance exam preparation courses;
home schooled students; Preparation Students should know a little chemistry and atomic models. Step 1: Research about molecular geometry Step 2: Create the model
  • Model Dalton (billiard ball) - 1803
  • Thomson model (plum pudding) - 1897
  • Model Rutherford-Bohr (planetary system) - 1908/1910
    • Results After printing students should be able to identify the different atomic models and their characteristics.

comments.text: Thank you so much for this my chemistry homework is done :D

For the seedlings I added a small tower with the same height to the print, because they are too thin to print alone. I printed them with ColorFabb CorkFill and green and orange PLA.

The Earth has its inner structure divided into three layers:
 
  • Lithosphere or crust Land: external and solid layer surrounding the Earth. It consists of rocks and soil of varying levels and consists of large amount of minerals.
    The lithosphere has thickness of about 72 km below the continents, which is called continental crust, and thickness of approximately 8 km below the oceans, which is called oceanic crust.
    The rocks that make up the lithosphere can be:
    • magmatic rocks or igneous rocks: are formed by magma located below the rocks which solidify.
    • Sedimentary rocks: Formed by the lack of debris caused by erosive action.
    • metamorphic rocks: Formed by magmatic and sedimentary rocks that have changed.
  • Robe: layer located just below the crust Earth and extends to almost half of the Earth's radius is formed by various types of rocks that due to high temperatures, are in paste form and receive the magma name.
     
  • Core: is the innermost layer of the planet and is about 1/3 of the entire mass of the Earth. It contains high temperatures and is believed to be formed by metals such as iron and nickel and other elements.

The modeling of these models is very simple, just model a ball and catch it 1/4. You can do this with intersections.
1/4 ball, you can duplicate them and make the intersection of smaller spheres.

Objectives To help students understand the layers of the earth and their connections, the core is inside the mantle and the crust on top of the mantle. Audiences high school;
geography classes;
entrance exam preparation courses;
home schooled students; Preparation Students should know a little geography and Structure of the Earth Step 1: Research about molecular geometry Step 2: Create the model The modeling of these models is very simple, just model a ball and catch it 1/4. You can do this with intersections. 1/4 ball, you can duplicate them and make the intersection of smaller spheres. Results To help students understand the layers of the earth and their connections, the core is inside the mantle and the crust on top of the mantle.
Made with PrintShop ShapeMaker

This is a very simple PTFE Tube holder which can be easily attached to a 20mm aliminum extruded profile. I used mine to guide the PTFE tube for bowden setup along the frame of my mendelmax 2.0 but the part can be attached to any 20mm extruded profile.
The fit is very tight and snug. If done carefully, the holder can be installed and removed about 5 times with no damage.
Just fit the base to the extruded profile, put your PTFE tube in the slot and then slide the locking cap in place. Can be used also for cable routing, etc.
Use with ABS only. PLA is not elastic enough and may break.

"Ballschnecke" based on a 1980's baby toy. The sphere inside the body spins when the snail is moved. Notes:

  • Full scale of the finished model is about 22.5 cm long and 15 cm high.
  • The model shown in the picture is printed at 40% scale which results in a length of about 9 cm.
  • The wheel axles can be made out of a nail, the axle holes may have to be drilled out depending on axle diameter.
  • The 2 halves of the body must be glued together with the sphere already placed inside.

comments.author: jasmino

title: Toshiba R850 power plug frame, inside labtop

description.text:
toshiba cyprus charge me 75 euro (8 euro from e-bay) when my laptop plug drop inside laptop, (they say they install new original toshiba plug).
After a month plug drop again inside and I open my laptop and i see that they put plug in place with silicone glue (take me an hour to clean old silicon glue remains).
so i decide to design my own plug repair (with out silicone this time) and it work WAY better than toshiba cyprus fixes and cheaper (10min printing, 0.26M 1gram).

This is a stand mount to your smartphone. I designed it after the planted avocado pit and thought it was nice to watch it grow. Unfortunately, as you can see in the picture, pip she could grow up before I finished the project.

Printer:

kossel mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30

At the beginning of the searched resources Thingiverse there are no finished project, but I have not found nothing that suited me. I decided to design something myself.
The main objective of the project was to document the growth of my avocado pits, but it can also be used to observe weather changes, and any phenomena slowly changing. Preparation To complete the project you need to print four necessary elements, prepare the seven screws approximately 10mm, spring (chosen experimentally) and one screw to the spring of about 6mm. In the photograph you can see all the necessary components and tools. Results Ready mount should be screwed to a tripod photo, set on the object and turn recording in your favorite app.. After a few hours / days of shooting a whole can be made in an interesting video showing the changes. I think that every biology teacher will appreciate the ability to use a smartphone.

description.text:
This mousetrap car is made out of simple geometric shapes in Tinkercad so it's adjustable in any way. With it you can learn about the lever principle and have much fun just playning around with it :)
Besides this you have a creative entry in the world of 3D design, physics and engeneering.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes: For best results print the chassis upside down!
You only need support for the chassis!

The idea of making this moustrap car, was to do a project students can learn something while having fun. So i thought about something which is cheap and relatively easy to build. I ended up with the plan of this mousetrap car.
I designed my chassis to make a standard moustrap easy to attach, just slide in and go! The wheels and the axis are also constructed with the view on effectivity and druability!
With my design beeing open source the students can manipulate my designs or just take the parameters and make a car that looks different. Maybe they want a Formula 1 car or a rally car? Just be creative!

Objectives Students can learn about the lever principle and achieve basic skills in CAD.
I made a clip-on-and-go lever for the mousetrap which is easy to adjust in length in Tinkercad. So the students can try how fast or how long the car can drive with different lever lengths!
For the entry in 3D design I took Tinkercad, because it's very intuitive and easy to use when you are new at CAD. So I hope to inspire students to be creative in 3D design. Audiences In my opinion this project is doable from the 5th grade upwards, with guidance in 3D design and 3D printing. Preparation Students should have a basic idea of 3D design (,a free Tinkercad account) and access to a 3D printer. Furthermore a mousetrap and a durable string are needed to build this project. Steps If you build this project I want you to follow your creative ideas! So i don't want you to draw this car exactly like I did. You can take my leverdesign and my mesurements for wheels and axis, also you can use my slide-in design for the mousetrape! But you should feel free to improve or redesign everything as you want it to be! Here you find my Tinkercad files: The chassis: https://tinkercad.com/things/1jGyos6hjFl The wheels: https://tinkercad.com/things/6c22w05xVHX The lever: https://tinkercad.com/things/cS7L9Yr9fUY Important sizes: It's important that the diameter of the holes in chassis fit the diameter of the axis with enough tolerance, so that the axis can move freely. For me a tolerance of +1mm worked pretty well! If you adjust the wheels/axis u need to make sure, that the tubes which are used to connect the axis, are adjusted as well to fit the new axis diameter as 'press fit' again! To make the moustrap fit the slide in mount you need to remove this wire on the backside with a screwdriver. How to adjust the lever length? (Lever: https://tinkercad.com/things/cS7L9Yr9fUY) Just drag the outline to adjust the lever! How to connect the axis? Just push the axis into the tube! Fruther you need to secure the string at the backaxle (just push it through the whole and make a knot) and attach the other end of the string to the lever (with another knot). How to clip on the lever? Just clip the lever on a bit carefully! How to make it drive? Just furl the string around the back axle until the moustrap is tensioned. Place it on the floor and release the trap. Hint: If you need more friction you can stick some (Velcro®-)tape around the wheels ;) Results Finally you should have your own working moustrap care in hand! Which lever length did you take? How far did your racer driver? What did you learn in terms of the lever principle and the distance your car reached? Maybe you make a challenge in your class?
I hope you had fun doing my project!

description.text:
I made a alternative case-flap for the NinTastic Raspberry Pi case by Francis Brown.
Thanks Francis for this nice retro case.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0a with E3D V6 hotend

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printed it with the letters up and added a pause (M0) for changing the color mid-print.

This is a chemical kit which contains 16 objects and which permits learning chemistry and biology.
This kit allows to observe nature and study it in a playful way.
The objects contained in this kit are:
  • Two boxes for containing chemicals
  • A funnel
  • A sample holder
  • Two test tube
  • A flat bottom
  • a beaker
  • an Erlenmeyer
  • A petri dish
  • A model of cell
  • A plant cell model
  • A model of virus
  • A model of bacterium
  • A clamp
  • A small spatula
  • A microscope for iPhone 5c
  • A model of an antibody

Printer:

k8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2mm

Infill:

20 %

Notes: To print the test tube, the flat bottom, the beaker, the Erlenmeyer and the petri dish use transparent filament. If you don't have transparent filament, you can buy it on http://www.amazon.com/HATCHBOX-Transparent-3D-Printer-Filament/dp/B00M0CS3B4/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1456499014&sr=8-5&keywords=filament+transpare.
If you want to print the image of the interior of the cell, you can download the "Document 1" file located in the file download.

In this section I'll talk about how I designed my 3D model.
Every pieces of this kit were made in cinema 4D. I just started with cinema 4D, and I have struggled to conceive my objects. In designating these objects I learned to use Cinema 4D. Here are some picture of my creations in cinema 4D. it is an image with all the designs that I made. It was a challenge for me to make this screw cap because I'd never do before. This design is more complicated. I spend a lot of time to create it. Before I draw on the computer I first made sketches. I printed model microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, animal and plant cells. The models allow students to more easily learn their lesson. They prefer to see a bacteria model than to see the bacteria on a 2D sheet of paper.
The models that I built is divided into two parts. So we can look inside the model. Inside the model I pasted a picture of the inside of a microorganism. Here is a model of a bacterium, it consists of three parts that can be assembled and disassembled to see the picture inside the bacteria. to the left is a plant cell image to the right we see the model of the plant cell. At the interior of the model, we see the picture I have pasted. This image is the interior of the plant cell. Here the model of virus, this model is also in 3 parts that can be assembled or disassembled to look inside the virus. I pasted a picture in the virus. In the background we see a picture of the virus micoscope. Here is a animal cell model. Top left an animal cell is seen under a microscope. Top right we see the image that I stuck in the cell. Here a model antibody.

Objectives
  • Design and create 3D printed tools to study nature.
  • Build complex designs.
  • Learn how to use cinema 4D or other modeling software.
  • Explore history of science.
    • Audiences
  • Anyone of any age that is new to 3D modeling can use this modeling project to get started with cinema 4D.
    • Preparation
  • Students will need access to computers with cinema 4D and a reliable internet connection.
  • Students should be familiar with Cinema 4D, this software is not simple to use.
    The professor explains to his students how to use the software.
  • The instructor should be comfortable answering modeling questions about cinema 4D and be able to advise students to avoid design features that might cause printing difficulties (overhangs, delicate features, etc).
  • It is helpful to have students form into working groups of two or three so that they can collaborate on the design process. Having students work in groups is also helpful if you have a limited number of computers and/or limited 3D printer access.
    • Step 1 Have each group of students choose one, two or three scientific tools to model. For example, they can take the microscope for iPhone, the petri dish, the clamp and a container. Step 2 Students should look for scientific image tools on google. The picture must be clear. Images found by students Step 3 Students make drawings on paper before going on their computer.
    Students can simplify the tools they have found on google. Step 4 Students can now model the scientific tools in cinema 4D. They must create objects that can be printed in 3D. Step 5 Students can now print their tools. They should check that their tools are in the right scale.
    Students found a lens in an old camera, they can use this lens to make the microscope. tools printed by students Step 6 Students go in nature and are looking for plants or materials (different kind of stone or plants).
    When they find a interressante plants, they put in the container with the clamp.
    After they return to their schools to discuss what they have found. They put the plant they found in the petri dish with the clamp, then they observe the plant with the microscope for iphone 5c. Step 7 Students can obtain information on the plant, for example by searching on google they learn that this plant is composed of plant cell. They also learn that the cell was discovered by Robert Hooke.
    They also modeled the cell and print it.
    Students can make a presentation on the plant they found. This is an effective way to study. Results At the end of this project, each group of students should have:
  • Records of any notes or research they did before the project.
  • An initial sketch of their tool scientific tools.
  • A sketch of their scientific tools.
  • Notes on improvements or iterations in their 3D model design.
  • 3D printed scientific tools.
    • Students learned to follow a protocol to produce a 3D object. They found a lot of information about the plants they found in nature. They will again full of other experience with other scientific tools. I'm 15 years old and I speak French. I'm sorry for my bad english.

The remix for flashforge fits well on my machine (Wanhao 4S), but my springs are both wider and taller, so I had to make my own version. Works perfectly now. I previously experimented with using rubber bands to keep the pieces from falling apart, but with this design it snaps perfectly together and holds in place without the rubber bands due to high friction from the springs.
Thanks to simonwlchan for the original concept and design. This eliminated vibrations through the floor entirely and I can now print at night without bothering my neighbours.
Springs used were 20mm tall springs, ID~6mm, OD~9mm

Animatronics Sunflower, more info here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bUM1gSby8ew
Please move the 3D files to the correct position before print them.
This animatronics needs more mechanical parts, not only 3D printed parts. For the file named "EncaixeOlho4mm" I recommend to do it in aluminium.
For the eyes moviment I have used universal joints like this one: http://pt.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-4-4mm-5-4mm-4-3mm-5-5mm-4-3-17mm-6-6mm-Metal-Universal/32464620728.html?spm=2114.02010208.3.32.MI0DmJ&ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_7,searchweb201644_2_505_506_503_504_10020_502_10001_10002_10017_10010_10005_10011_10006_10003_10021_10004_10022_10009_10008_10018_10019,searchweb201560_3,searchweb1451318400_-1,searchweb1451318411_6448&btsid=946a93d7-f91b-4a02-bb26-d88c7e7c707b
I used the 4mm x 5mm.
For the mouth movement I used turnige servos: https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=27558 For the rest I used Hobbico CS60 servos. In order to make the blinking eyes mechanism, it is necessary to use an LM8UU linear bearing http://pt.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-LM8UU-8mm-Linear-Ball-Bearing-Bushing-Linear-Bearings-CNC-parts-3d-printer-parts/2039687759.html?spm=2114.02010208.3.10.T2t6g5&ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_7,searchweb201644_2_505_506_503_504_10020_502_10001_10002_10017_10010_10005_10011_10006_10003_10021_10004_10022_10009_10008_10018_10019,searchweb201560_3,searchweb1451318400_-1,searchweb1451318411_6448&btsid=0a0d9e29-fa61-439a-b15e-7e1f0fbbe605 and a piece of 8mm smooth rod.

comments.text:
Hi Tony,
Actually I'm building this prototype.
http://hpics.li/42b0078
It's working, but not ideal. I'm using a DC motor salvage from cordless drill and it 's not easy to control the speed of the wheel.
The small spool inside the wheel is not an ideal solution too, the quantity of wire is small and useful only for fine wire.
I'm designing a new one with a "hollow" wheel and a slider. It seems that it will be a more versatile solution but not easy to design I'm afraid... ;)
comments.author: 3DChannel

comments.text:
Hi Scarou,
the problem is to synchronize the two rotations (horizontal and vertical).
You can go two ways.
The first, involves the use of a mechanical coupling between the two rotations with a fixed parameter (in this case you can continue to use dc motor).
The second solution is to use two motors driven by Arduino nano, and to realize a software that allows to vary the rotation parameter depending on the size of the coil to achieve.
comments.author: scarou

comments.text:
Actually I use a DC motor and I make the toroidal core rotation by hand. The result is of course not perfect but it is a huge improvement related to hand winding a coil.
Even if you motorize the core rotation, you can still use a DC motor for the winding move. You just need a sensor to trigger the core movement. If you use a counter (you might use one for winding with no stress...) you just have to pickup the signal to trigger a move of a stepper motor for example (not so complicated with an arduino , a stepper driver and a stepper motor).

This is a portable sheet music holder which I have designed for my daughters flute lessons.
The arms can be fold away. Tip: Try out GCode Simulator to check your print upfront
On Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44286
GCodePrintr - 3D printing from an Android device
Homepage: http://gcodeprintr.dietzm.de

Printer:

Multec Multirap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes: The holder requires a large print bet of 160mmx285mm. Or you need to scale it down.
The openscad model is included to adjust the size.
You need two flat head screws to attach the foldaway arms.
Designed using OpenSCAD

description.text: Why not
This model of the heroe Pudge with Dota 2 is built out of 3d official model.  Took support in meshmixer. It is model for funs for dota.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Infill:

15%

I took the 3D model from the official source. Then with a few programs I repartition in the STL format. After the program I added a blender change circle and the size of the model, also added a nickname for someone model and added the game logo. Then Meshmixer added support.
Since the gaming industry is very developed in our time. I think a lot of guys like the idea of printing their favorite characters from the games.

author: DogFight

description.text: LLavero Club Belgrano de Cordoba

Just a simple wire strain reliever. I use this instead of heat shrink. I included the sketch up file for modification. Just print 2 and glue them together around the wire. CA glue works awesome. Super simple design and easy to print. I might update it later so it snaps together but feel free to remix with that feature or to just make it look nicer. 
obviously follow all safety precautions that are necessary when working with electronics. when putting around multiple wires, make sure to insulate them from each other. 
this one has an ID of 2.2 (4.4 when both are printed and joined) mm but I am sure most people will need to modify.
This is a camel meeple to be used for board and tabletop gaming. It is designed after the camel meeple from the Voyages of Marco Polo.

comments.author: Fhrisanfow

description.text: waikiki - old fashion

This is an Archimedes screw. Attributed to Archimedes over 2000 years ago this is a very early water pump. The screw sits in a tube or half pipe and draws the water up when spun.
This model had a stand with half pipe, screw and key, and an additional half pipe to seal the tube.
Sand well. The tolerances are tight and if there are any jags from supports then it will not draw water.

comments.text: I was watching a documentary the other night on Nova and the idea of the Archimedes screw came up well over 500 years before Archimedes https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aJTWai6xKM4

comments.text: Printed this out of standard PLA with 100% infill and it stripped in just a couple uses. Picked up some high-strength Polymaker PC-Max and will be trying it again...
comments.author: qhartman

comments.text: OK, used this with PC-max, and it still stripped out right away. It lasted better than the PLA, but still not long enough to be worth the trouble in my case. The drive shaft on my grinder is particularly stripped, so it's possible that it's just too rounded for this to be a viable solution.
